awd_titl_txt: Wavelength Scaling of Plasma and Spatio-Temporal Dynamics of Laser Filamentation in Solids
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will improve the understanding of the physical mechanisms and the spatio-temporal dynamics of laser filamentation in solids.  Laser filamentation is self-guidance of a high-power laser pulse propagating through a gas, liquid or solid material when self-focusing of the pulse is balanced by defocusing due to the laser-induced modifications in the material.  This remarkable phenomenon finds a lot of applications such as table-top ultraviolet and x-ray generation, lightning guiding, rainmaking, selective radiotherapy on cancer cells, long-lived waveguides in air, and remote sensing of pollutants.  This project will also promote basic science education to groups, such as grandparent-led rural families, who have been traditionally underrepresented in science.

Laser filamentation is self-guidance of a high-power laser pulse when self-focusing due to the optical Kerr effect is balanced by defocusing due to material ionization and/or other nonlinear mechanisms.  Although laser filamentation has been studied mainly using near-infrared and visible wavelengths, recent progress in ultrafast laser technology enables the investigation of laser filamentation using longer wavelengths such as mid-infrared and long-wavelength infrared.  In this project, laser filamentation in solids will be experimentally studied by measuring plasma densities directly inside the filaments, with the experiments guided by 3-dimensional computer simulations of laser matter interactions.  The project will impact filament-based technology such as new ultrabroadband and ultrashort light generation for spectroscopy and optical communications.

por.por_cntn:
Bonggu Shim, PI, Binghamton University, NSF 1707237: Wavelength Scaling of Plasma and Spatio-Temporal Dynamics of Laser Filamentation in Solids

One of the important topics for high-intensity laser matter interactions involving plasma (a state of matter with electrons and ions) is laser filamentation which is self-guidance of a high-power laser pulse via the balance between self-focusing called optical Kerr effect and plasma-induced defocusing due to material ionization. This remarkable phenomenon finds a lot of applications such as broadband and ultrashort pulse generation, table-top ultraviolet and x-ray generation, remote sensing of pollutants, and lightning guiding. Although laser filamentation was studied mainly using near-infrared and visible light, recent progress in ultrafast laser technology has enabled the investigation of laser filamentation using longer wavelengths such as mid-infrared. In this project, laser filamentation in solids has been experimentally studied using ultrashort tunable wavelength sources in the PI's group. In addition, experimental research has been supported and guided by sophisticated computer simulations for laser matter interactions. In detail,

1) We have successfully implemented frequency-domain holography (FDH) which is a state-of-the-art single-shot spatio-temporal visualization technique which enables measurements of high intensity laser matter interactions including laser filamentation on ultrashort time scales. Using FDH, we were able to capture the moment of optical damage in flexible thin (100 micrometer) glass irradiated by a high-power laser pulse. To the best of the PI's knowledge, this is the first single-shot spatio-temporal  visualization of optical damage and plasma generation in glass.

2) We have successfully implemented highly-sophisticated laser-matter interaction simulation codes called unidirectional pulse propagation equation (UPPE) codes to theoretically study ultrashort laser pulse propagation in nonlinear media such as laser filamentation. The UPPE codes and other existing laser-plasma interaction codes of the PI's group have successfully guided and explained the experiments carried out by the PI's group as well as collaborators such as MIT and University of Central Florida.

3)  We have experimentally and theoretically investigated wavelength scaling of plasma dynamics and, in particular, the electron collision time in plasma for laser filamentation in solids. Although the dielectric constant of plasma is a function of not only optical frequency and plasma density but also electron collision time (frequency), there are only a handful of experiments on the electron collision time and, to the best of the PI's knowledge, there was no wavelength-scaled study on it and its critical role in laser plasma interactions. Our experiment using time-resolved interferometry revealed that the electron collision time is small (< one femtosecond: one quadrillionth of a second) and decreases with increasing wavelength in laser filamentation in solids, which critically affects the dynamics of wavelength-dependent laser matter interactions. Thus, electron collision times in plasma should be systematically investigated for a better understanding of strong field laser matter interactions, in particular, in solids.

Furthermore, the PI's group has been promoting basic science education including plasma, lasers, and optics to groups who have been traditionally underrepresented in science in Broome County of NY state by hosting science camps for grandparent-headed families and for middle school students of rural families. Based on this experience, we presented a poster entitled "Meeting the Science and Mathematics Education Needs of Grandparent-Headed Families" in the American Association of Physics Teachers (AAPT) Summer Meeting in Washington DC in 2018.

In this project, total 4 graduate students and 4 undergraduate students have been supported and trained. R. Grynko finished his PhD degree and received a Graduate Student Award for Excellence in Research from Binghamton University in 2017. A graduate student, D. Dempsey, won the first-place prize in the student poster competition of the 30th annual Electronics Packaging Symposium in 2019 and also won the poster award in the energy technical group poster session in Conference of Lasers and Electro-Optics (CLEO) 2019 which is one of the largest laser and optics conferences in the world.
